definition:
The are a family of transforms closely related to the discrete cosine
transform and the discrete Fourier transform. The set of variants of the
DST was first introduced by Wang and Hunt [@DWT].

Definition
==========

The orthonormal variants of the DST, where $x_n$ is the original vector
of $N$ real numbers, $C_k$ is the transformed vector of $N$ real numbers
and $\delta$ is the Kronecker delta, are defined by the following
equations:

DST-I
-----

$$\begin{aligned}
S^{I}_k&=&p \sum _{n=0}^{N-1} x_n \sin \frac{\pi (n+1) (k+1)}{N+1} \quad \quad k=0, 1, 2, \dots, N-1\\
p&=&\sqrt{\frac{2}{N+1}}\end{aligned}$$

The DST-I is its own inverse.

DST-II
------

$$\begin{aligned}
S^{II}_k&=&p_k \sum _{n=0}^{N-1} x_n \sin \frac{\pi \left(n+\frac{1}{2}\right) (k+1)}{N} \quad \quad k=0, 1, 2, \dots, N-1\\
p_k&=&\sqrt{\frac{2-\delta _{k,0}}{N}}\end{aligned}$$

The inverse of DST-II is DST-III.

DST-III
-------

$$\begin{aligned}
S^{III}_k&=&p \sum _{n=0}^{N-1} x_n q_n \sin \frac{\pi (n+1) \left(k+\frac{1}{2}\right)}{N} \quad \quad k=0, 1, 2, \dots, N-1\\
p&=&\sqrt{\frac{2}{N}}\\
q_n&=&\sqrt{\frac{1}{1+\delta _{n,0}}}\end{aligned}$$

The inverse of DST-III is DST-II.

DST-IV
------

$$\begin{aligned}
S^{IV}_k&=&p \sum _{n=0}^{N-1} x_n \sin \frac{\pi \left(n+\frac{1}{2}\right) \left(k+\frac{1}{2}\right)}{N} \quad \quad k=0, 1, 2, \dots, N-1\\
p&=&\sqrt{\frac{2}{N}}\end{aligned}$$

The DST-IV is its own inverse.

DST-V
-----

$$\begin{aligned}
S^V_k&=&p \sum _{n=0}^{N-1} x_n \sin \frac{\pi (n+1) (k+1)}{N+\frac{1}{2}} \quad \quad k=0, 1, 2, \dots, N-1\\
p&=&\sqrt{\frac{2}{N+\frac{1}{2}}}\end{aligned}$$

The DST-V is its own inverse.

DST-VI
------

$$\begin{aligned}
S^{VI}_k&=&p \sum _{n=0}^{N-1} x_n \sin \frac{\pi \left(n+\frac{1}{2}\right) (k+1)}{N+\frac{1}{2}} \quad \quad k=0, 1, 2, \dots, N-1\\
p&=&\sqrt{\frac{2}{N+\frac{1}{2}}}\end{aligned}$$

The inverse of DST-VI is DST-VII.

DST-VII
-------

$$\begin{aligned}
S^{VII}_k&=&p \sum _{n=0}^{N-1} x_n \sin \frac{\pi (n+1) \left(k+\frac{1}{2}\right)}{N+\frac{1}{2}} \quad \quad k=0, 1, 2, \dots, N-1\\
p&=&\sqrt{\frac{2}{N+\frac{1}{2}}}\end{aligned}$$

The inverse of DST-VII is DST-VI.

DST-VIII
--------

$$\begin{aligned}
S^{VIII}_k&=&p_k \sum _{n=0}^{N-1} x_n q_n \sin \frac{\pi \left(n+\frac{1}{2}\right) \left(k+\frac{1}{2}\right)}{N-\frac{1}{2}} \quad \quad k=0, 1, 2, \dots, N-1\\
p_k&=&\sqrt{\frac{2-\delta _{k,N-1}}{N-\frac{1}{2}}}\\
q_n&=&\sqrt{\frac{1}{1+\delta _{n,N-1}}}\end{aligned}$$

The DST-VIII is its own inverse.

Two-dimensional DST
===================

The DST in two dimensions is simply the one-dimensional transform
computed in each row and each column. For example, the DST-II of a
$N_1\times N_2$ matrix is given by

$$\begin{aligned}
S^{II}_{k_1,k_2}&=&p_{k_1}p_{k_2}\sum _{n_1=0}^{N_1-1}\sum _{n_2=0}^{N_2-1} x_{n_1,n_2} \sin \frac{\pi \left(n_1+\frac{1}{2}\right) (k_1+1)}{N_1} \sin \frac{\pi \left(n_2+\frac{1}{2}\right) (k_2+1)}{N_2}\end{aligned}$$
